   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 78 y/o M h/o CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer
   who presents with new onset A. Fib with RVR and MSSA bacteremia, now
   with respiratory failure and ARF.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Presented with subacute exacerbation with
   decline over past 3-4 weeks.  Has COPD at baseline. Patient was
   electively intubated on [**3-11**] to perform multiple procedures.  Difficulty
   weaning patient from the ventilator initially due to fluid retention
   and baseline COPD. [**Month (only) 11**] be extubatable today as pt doing well on minimal
   pressure support with minimal secretions. Pt more alert. Pt is 17L
   positive over LOS however will not diurese given ARF.  Tube feeds held
   overnight.
   - re-intubated for respiratory failure
   .
   # Fever/bacteremia:  Blood cultures 3/4 MSSA. BCx from anerobic bottle
   on [**3-14**] showing GNR. Sputum also showing enterobacter cloacae (sensitive
   to cefepime and cipro), likely representing VAP (however mini-BAL
   negative).
   - Switched abx from nafcillin (received 6 days
 worth, [**Date range (1) 4714**]), to
   Cipro, Cefepime and Flagyl (started evening of [**3-15**])
   - F/u final BCx and speciation/sensi studies to further tailor abx.
   - F/u ID recs (consider TEE in [**1-7**] weeks and CT torso when feasible)
   - f/u pending micro studies
   .
   # ARF: Most likely, initially pre-renal then tipped over to ATN. No
   urine eos, thus unlikely AIN due to Nafcillin. No hydronephrosis per CT
   scan.  Mass lesion on the left previously seen on CT done [**2174-2-6**] at
   BIDN. Cr now somewhat stable in 4+ range.
   - Trend lytes
   - Renal c/s
 no need for HD at this time, treat hyperphosphatemia with
   Renagel and increase dose of AlOH. If renal fxn worsens, consider
   biopsy
   - Renally dose meds
   .
   # Septic arthritis / gout: Patient septic arthritis combined with gouty
   arthritis in multiple joints.  Orthopedics took patient to the OR for
   washout on [**3-12**] and all joints tapped have bacteria on gram stain.
   Assistance and recs from ortho and rheum are much appreciated.  Ortho
   is watching right wrist and may consider repeat washout in future.
   - colchicine off given elevated creatinine
   - Slow taper of steroids started [**3-14**]
   - F/u ortho recs
 ask if further procedures are planned in near future
   .
   # Tachycardia: Resolved.  Initially presented with A. Fib with RVR
   appears to be a new diagnosis for this patient.  Likely not a candidate
   for coumadin given recent GI bleed and colon cancer.  Patient has ruled
   out for an MI. Had TEE on [**3-11**] that showed no clot.  Patient converted
   to NSR post-TEE in the setting of hyperkalemia and has remained in NSR
   after electrolyte correction.  Appreciate assistance from EP. Appears
   to have gone back into a-fib in the AM of [**3-18**]
   - EKG in AM
   - Metoprolol IV for a-fib
   - continue amiodarone per NG
   - notify EP when patient stable and leaving the unit to repeat
   assessment of his device (note they changed his baseline pacing rate to
   60 bpm on [**3-11**]).
   .
   # Abdominal pain: The patient did not have any abdominal pain on
   presentation.  He had mild discomfort on exam over the weekend which is
   stable.  Abdominal ultrasound also noted sludge in the gallbladder, no
   other findings noted.  Pain could be secondary to a bilary process,
   bacteremia (?abdominal abscess), or some other process related to his
   colon cancer.
   - Trend LFTs
 elevated Tbili, other LFTs and lipase nl
   - RUQ U/S showing cholelithiasis, no cholecystitis.
   .
   # Anemia: likely GIB from colon cancer and anemia of chronic dz.
   Patient transfused with 1 unit on am of [**3-13**] and 2 U [**3-14**]. Haptoglobin
   not decreased and LDH not largely elevated, so hemolysis less likely.
   Guaiac pos yesterday
   - per BIDN records, baseline Hct 35-37. Pt presented in [**2174-2-6**] with
   hct drop to 23 then was diagnosed with invasive colon ca.
   - goal Hct >22; judicious RBC transfusions.
   .
   # Colon Ca: No known mets but with extensive lymphadenopathy in chest
   on last CT scan.
   - had a colorectal outpt appt scheduled for today; will defer this
   issue until pt extubated and stabilized.
   .
   # Pressure Ulcers:
   - local wound care, frequent turns
   .
   # Hyperglycemia: no h/o diabetes by chart.  HbA1c 6.7.  Continue
   humalog sliding scale q6h for now, given steroids.
   .
   # Glaucoma: continue eye drops
   - confirm pilocarpine dosing from outpatient setting.
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, ISS. NGT placed. Tube feeds.
   .

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, and recently diagnosed colon cancer. He presented with new onset atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, septic arthritis, gout, tachycardia, abdominal pain, anemia, and hyperglycemia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's baseline COPD and fluid retention have made it difficult to wean him off the ventilator. There is a risk of prolonged mechanical ventilation or further deterioration in respiratory function.
2. Bacteremia and Sepsis: The presence of MSSA bacteremia and other bacteria in the blood cultures indicates a risk of sepsis. This could lead to organ dysfunction and potentially worsen the patient's overall condition.
3. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient has pre-renal azotemia followed by acute tubular necrosis. It is crucial to monitor renal function closely and manage fluid and electrolyte imbalances to prevent further renal damage.
4. Septic Arthritis and Gout: The patient has septic arthritis combined with gouty arthritis in multiple joints. This poses a risk of joint destruction and systemic complications.
5. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia, initially attributed to atrial fibrillation, has resolved but may recur. Appropriate management is necessary to prevent cardiac complications.
6. Abdom

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 78 y/o M h/o CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer
   who presents with new onset A. Fib with RVR and MSSA bacteremia, now
   with respiratory failure and ARF.
   .
   # Hemodynamic instability: Initially presented with A. Fib with RVR
   appears to be a new diagnosis for this patient, which was controlled
   with amiodarone.  Likely not a candidate for coumadin given recent GI
   bleed and colon cancer.  Patient has ruled out for an MI. Had TEE on
   [**3-11**] that showed no clot.  Patient converted to NSR post-TEE in the
   setting of hyperkalemia and has remained in NSR after electrolyte
   correction.  Appreciate assistance from EP. Appears to have gone back
   into a-fib in the AM of [**3-18**] in setting of hypoxemia.
   - EKG in AM
   - Fluid boluses  and metoprolol IV x1 to attempt cardioversion, will
   speak with family re: cardioversion/TEE for presumed endocarditis
   - continue amiodarone per NG, consider rebolus as hemodynamics improve
   when patient is in NSR, if family wishes
   - notify EP when patient stable and leaving the unit to repeat
   assessment of his device (note they changed his baseline pacing rate to
   60 bpm on [**3-11**]).
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Presented with subacute exacerbation with
   decline over past 3-4 weeks.  Has COPD at baseline. Patient was
   electively intubated on [**3-11**] to perform multiple procedures.  Difficulty
   weaning patient from the ventilator initially due to fluid retention
   and baseline COPD. Extubated afternoon of [**3-17**]. Pt more alert. Pt is
   17L positive over LOS however will not diurese given ARF.  Tube feeds
   held overnight.
   - re-intubated for worsening acidosis and hypoventilation with fatigue
   overnight
   - Will speak with family regarding long-term ventilator assist as it
   may be increasingly difficult to wean patient in light of recent
   decline.
   .
   # Fever/bacteremia:  Blood cultures 3/4 MSSA in setting of metastatic
   seeding of gouty joints
 likely due to endocarditis. Additional data
   is worsening necrosis of toes and mottling of L foot. BCx from anerobic
   bottle on [**3-14**] showing GNR. Sputum also showing enterobacter cloacae
   (sensitive to cefepime and cipro), likely representing VAP (however
   mini-BAL negative).
   - Switched abx from nafcillin (received 6 days
 worth, [**Date range (1) 4714**]), to
   Cipro, Cefepime and Flagyl (started evening of [**3-15**])
   - F/u final BCx and speciation/sensi studies to further tailor abx.
   - F/u ID recs (consider TEE in [**1-7**] weeks and CT torso when feasible)
   - f/u pending micro studies
   .
   # ARF: Most likely, initially pre-renal then tipped over to ATN. No
   urine eos, thus unlikely AIN due to nafcillin. No hydronephrosis per CT
   scan.  Mass lesion on the left previously seen on CT done [**2174-2-6**] at
   BIDN. Cr now somewhat stable in 4+ range.
   - Trend lytes
   - Renal c/s
 treat hyperphosphatemia with Renagel and increase dose of
   AlOH. If renal fxn worsens, consider biopsy
   - Will consider HD, per family wishes, as situation is now very grave
   with worsening UOP after it had picked up over the past 2 days.
   - Renally dose meds
   .
   # Septic arthritis / gout: Patient septic arthritis combined with gouty
   arthritis in multiple joints.  Orthopedics took patient to the OR for
   washout on [**3-12**] and all joints tapped have bacteria on gram stain.
   Assistance and recs from ortho and rheum are much appreciated.  Ortho
   is watching right wrist and may consider repeat washout in future.
   - colchicine off given elevated creatinine
   - Continue slow taper of steroids started [**3-14**]
   - F/u ortho recs
 No plan for future procedures
   .
   # Abdominal pain: Unable to assess recently in light of intubation and
   sedation. The patient did not have any abdominal pain on presentation.
   He had mild discomfort on exam over the weekend which is stable.
   Abdominal ultrasound also noted sludge in the gallbladder, no other
   findings noted.  Pain could be secondary to a bilary process,
   bacteremia (?abdominal abscess), or some other process related to his
   colon cancer.
   - Trend LFTs
 elevated Tbili, other LFTs and lipase nl
   - RUQ U/S showing cholelithiasis, no cholecystitis.
   .
   # Anemia: likely GIB from colon cancer and anemia of chronic dz.
   Patient transfused with 1 unit on am of [**3-13**] and 2 U [**3-14**]. Haptoglobin
   not decreased and LDH not largely elevated, so hemolysis less likely.
   Guaiac pos yesterday
   - per BIDN records, baseline Hct 35-37.
   - goal Hct >22; judicious RBC transfusions.
   - Also exhibiting platelet drop, which might be multifactorial,
   including HIT, uremia and DIC.
   .
   # Colon Ca: No known mets but with extensive lymphadenopathy in chest
   on last CT scan.
   - had a colorectal outpt appt scheduled for today; will defer this
   issue until pt extubated and stabilized.
   .
   # Pressure Ulcers:
   - local wound care, frequent turns, monitor areas of peripheral
   necrosis
   .
   # Hyperglycemia: no h/o diabetes by chart.  HbA1c 6.7.  Continue
   humalog sliding scale q6h for now, given steroids.
   .
   # Glaucoma: continue eye drops
   - confirm pilocarpine dosing from outpatient setting.
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, ISS. NGT placed. Tube feeds.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: HSC, pneumoboots, PPI
   .
   # Access: A-line ([**2174-3-11**]), and R IJ central line d/c
d [**3-17**] (placed
   [**2174-3-11**]), RUE PICC (placed [**3-17**])
   .
   # Code: DNR.  OK to re-intubate. Okay to turn off AICD if firing
   repetitively.
   .
   # Communication: Patient,  Wife
   .
   # Disposition: Requires ICU level of care.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, and recently diagnosed colon cancer. The patient presented with new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and was treated with amiodarone. He also had MSSA bacteremia and respiratory failure. The patient was initially intubated for multiple procedures and had difficulty weaning off the ventilator due to fluid retention and baseline COPD. He was extubated in the afternoon but reintubated in the morning for worsening acidosis and hypoventilation. The patient's toes show signs of necrosis, and there is mottling in his left foot with decreased pulses. Blood cultures showed MSSA and enterobacter cloacae, which are likely due to endocarditis. The patient was started on ciprofloxacin, cefepime, and flagyl. 

The patient also has acute kidney injury (ARF) with pre-renal azotemia tipping over to acute tubular necrosis. His urine output has improved but remains low, and his creatinine levels are stable in the 4+ range. The patient's electrolytes need to be trended, and renal consults should be obtained. 

The patient has septic arthritis combined with gouty arthritis in multiple joints, and orthopedic consultation is recommended. 

The patient's abdominal pain is likely due to a biliary process or bacteremia.

The patient is currently on morphine drip with Neo prn to support blood pressure. The AICD was turned off by the EP. Non-crushable medications were discontinued.

The patient received antibiotics, including ciprofloxacin, cefepime, and metronidazole, within the last 24 hours. They are receiving infusions of morphine sulfate, amiodarone, and phenylephrine. Other ICU medications include metoprolol and additional doses of morphine sulfate.

Fluid balance shows a total intake of 3,859 mL, including 633 mL of IV fluids. Output includes 1,369 mL of blood products, 1,069 mL of urine, and 300 mL of NG and stool drainage. The respiratory support is provided through an endotracheal tube with CMV

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, and recently diagnosed colon cancer.
- The patient presented with new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and MSSA bacteremia, now with respiratory failure and acute renal failure.
- The patient's hemodynamic instability was initially managed with amiodarone. He converted to sinus rhythm post-transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) and has remained in sinus rhythm after electrolyte correction.
- The patient's respiratory failure is due to a subacute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and fluid retention. He was electively intubated for multiple procedures and had difficulty weaning from the ventilator.
- The patient has been diagnosed with MSSA bacteremia, possibly due to metastatic seeding of gouty joints and suspected endocarditis. Additional data includes worsening necrosis of toes and mottling of the left foot.
- The patient's acute renal failure (ARF) is likely pre-renal initially, then tipped over to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). There is no evidence of analgesic-induced nephropathy (AIN) or hydronephrosis.
- The patient has septic arthritis/gouty arthritis in multiple joints and underwent washout of infected joints. He also has a mass lesion on the left previously seen on CT scan.
- The patient's abdominal pain

Fib) with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia, now with respiratory failure and acute renal failure (ARF). The patient's overall goal of care is to continue pressors for blood pressure support and low-dose morphine drip for pain control. The patient's family has decided to forego further aggressive care or interventions, but not officially code status.

The patient initially presented with A. Fib with RVR and appears to be a new diagnosis for this patient. The patient converted to normal sinus rhythm (NSR) post-transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) in the setting of hyperkalemia and remained in NSR after electrolyte correction. Then, the patient reverted back to A. fib yesterday morning but converted to SR with intravenous amiodarone. The patient was hemodynamically better when in NSR. It is likely that the patient is not a candidate for warfarin given recent gastrointestinal (GI) bleed and colon cancer. The patient has ruled out for an acute myocardial infarction (MI). A TEE on [**3-11**] showed no clot.

Summary:
- The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of CAD, CHF, and colon cancer.
- He presents with new onset atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, and acute renal failure.
- The patient has been treated with IV amiodarone, morphine, and phenylephrine.
- He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation.
- Blood cultures show MSSA bacteremia, and sputum shows budding yeast, suggesting possible VAP.
- The patient has necrosis of toes and mottling of the left foot, indicating potential severe infection.
- He is anemic and has a platelet drop, which may be due to gastrointestinal bleeding, chronic disease, or other causes.
- The patient has pressure ulcers and hyperglycemia, with a history of diabetes.
- He has glaucoma and requires prophylaxis for stress ulcers, deep vein thrombosis, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.
- The patient's code status is DNR, but it is okay to re-intubate and turn off the AICD if firing repetitively.
- The patient requires ICU level of care.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory function is compromised, necessitating mechanical ventilation. There is a risk of further deterioration and potential complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

2. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's renal function is impaired, evident

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old man with a history of colon cancer, atrial fibrillation, and an implanted cardioverter-defibrillator.    This is a 78 y/o M h/o CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer
   who presents with new onset A. Fib with RVR and MSSA bacteremia, now
   with respiratory failure and ARF.
   .
   # Overall goal of care: Pt gravely ill, with bacteremia, hypotension,
   ARF and respiratory failure. After family meeting yesterday, family
   decided to forego further aggressive care or interventions, however not
   CMO. Will continue pressors for BP support and low-dose morphine gtt
   for pain control. Please see Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 242**]
s note from yesterday for
   details.
   .
   # Hemodynamic instability: Initially presented with A. Fib with RVR
   appears to be a new diagnosis for this patient. Patient converted to
   NSR post-TEE in the setting of hyperkalemia, and remained in NSR after
   electrolyte correction. Then back in A. fib yesterday AM but converted
   to SR with IV amio. Hemodynamically better when in NSR. Likely not a
   candidate for coumadin given recent GI bleed and colon cancer.  Patient
   has ruled out for an MI. Had TEE on [**3-11**] that showed no clot.
   - switch IV amio to PO
   - AICD turned off per family wishes given gravity of pt
s overall
   condition. Appreciate EP help.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Presented with subacute exacerbation with
   decline over past 3-4 weeks.  Has COPD at baseline. Patient was
   electively intubated on [**3-11**] to perform multiple procedures.  Difficulty
   weaning patient from the ventilator initially due to fluid retention
   and baseline COPD. Extubated afternoon of [**3-17**] but re-intubated [**3-18**] AM
   for increased work of breathing and tachypnea, worsening acidosis. Pt
   is 20L positive over LOS however will not diurese given ARF.  Tube
   feeds held overnight.
   - Continue mech ventilation until further direction from family.
   .
   # Fever/bacteremia:  Blood cultures 3/4 MSSA in setting of metastatic
   seeding of gouty joints
 likely due to endocarditis. Additional data
   is worsening necrosis of toes and mottling of L foot. BCx from anerobic
   bottle on [**3-14**] showing GNR. Sputum also showing enterobacter cloacae
   (sensitive to cefepime and cipro), likely representing VAP (however
   mini-BAL negative).
   - Switched abx from nafcillin (received 6 days
 worth, [**Date range (1) 4714**]), to
   Cipro, Cefepime and Flagyl (started evening of [**3-15**])
   - F/u final BCx and speciation/sensi studies to further tailor abx.
   - F/u ID recs (consider TEE in [**1-7**] weeks and CT torso when feasible)
   - f/u pending micro studies
   .
   # ARF: Most likely, initially pre-renal then tipped over to ATN. No
   urine eos, thus unlikely AIN due to nafcillin. No hydronephrosis per CT
   scan.  Mass lesion on the left previously seen on CT done [**2174-2-6**] at
   BIDN. Cr now somewhat stable in 4+ range.
   - Trend lytes
   - Renal c/s
 treat hyperphosphatemia with Renagel and increase dose of
   AlOH. No hemodialysis or biopsy as pt does not want aggressive
   interventions.
   - Renally dose meds
   .
   # Septic arthritis / gout: Patient septic arthritis combined with gouty
   arthritis in multiple joints.  Orthopedics took patient to the OR for
   washout on [**3-12**] and all joints tapped have bacteria on gram stain.
   Assistance and recs from ortho and rheum are much appreciated.
   - family does not wish any further procedures
   - colchicine off given elevated creatinine
   - Continue slow taper of steroids started [**3-14**]
   - Appreciate ortho recs
   .
   # Abdominal pain: Unable to assess recently in light of intubation and
   sedation. The patient did not have any abdominal pain on presentation.
   He had mild discomfort on exam over the weekend which is stable.
   Abdominal ultrasound also noted sludge in the gallbladder, no other
   findings noted.  Pain could be secondary to a bilary process,
   bacteremia (?abdominal abscess), or some other process related to his
   colon cancer.
   - Trend LFTs
 elevated Tbili, other LFTs and lipase nl
   - RUQ U/S showing cholelithiasis, no cholecystitis.
   .
   # Anemia: likely GIB from colon cancer and anemia of chronic dz.
   Patient transfused with 1 unit on am of [**3-13**] and 2 U [**3-14**]. Haptoglobin
   not decreased and LDH not largely elevated, so hemolysis less likely.
   Guaiac pos [**3-17**]
   - per BIDN records, baseline Hct 35-37.
   - goal Hct >22; judicious RBC transfusions.
   - Also exhibiting platelet drop, which might be multifactorial,
   including HIT and low-grade DIC.
   .
   # Colon Ca: No known mets but with extensive lymphadenopathy in chest
   on last CT scan.
   - had a colorectal outpt appt scheduled for [**3-16**]; will defer this issue
   until pt extubated and stabilized.
   .
   # Pressure Ulcers:
   - local wound care, frequent turns, monitor areas of peripheral
   necrosis
   .
   # Hyperglycemia: no h/o diabetes by chart.  HbA1c 6.7.  Continue
   humalog sliding scale q6h for now, given steroids.
   .
   # Glaucoma: continue eye drops
   - confirm pilocarpine dosing from outpatient setting.
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, ISS. NGT placed. Tube feeds.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: HSC, pneumoboots, PPI
   .
   # Access: A-line ([**2174-3-11**]), and R IJ central line d/c
d [**3-17**] (placed
   [**2174-3-11**]), RUE PICC (placed [**3-17**])
   .
   # Code: DNR/I. Code discussion on-going with family.
   .
   # Communication: Patient,  Wife
   .
   # Disposition: Requires ICU level of care.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), congestive heart failure (CHF), and recently diagnosed colon cancer. He presents with new-onset atrial fibrillation (A. fib) with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia, respiratory failure, and acute renal failure (ARF).

The patient's overall goal of care is to continue with pressors for blood pressure support and low-dose morphine for pain control. The family has decided to forego further aggressive care or interventions, but not the comfort measures.

Hemodynamic instability: The patient initially presented with A. fib with RVR, which appears to be a new diagnosis. He converted to normal sinus rhythm (NSR) post-transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) in the setting of hyperkalemia and remained in NSR after electrolyte correction. However, he went back into A. fib the previous evening despite continuing amiodarone. The patient is likely not a candidate for coumadin given his recent gastrointestinal bleed and colon cancer. He has ruled out for an MI, and a TEE on [**3-11**] showed no clot. The plan is to switch IV amiodarone to oral and turn off the implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) per family wishes

The patient has right and left lower extremity edema, necrotic toes on the right foot, and a mottled left foot with decreased pulses and a shallow ulcer on the dorsal foot. 

The patient's lab results show elevated levels of white blood cells, hemoglobin, glucose, and lactate, as well as decreased levels of platelets and albumin. The patient's electrolytes are within normal range, except for slightly low potassium and magnesium levels. 

The patient has been receiving various medications and treatments, including antibiotics, fluids, and respiratory support through mechanical ventilation.

   This is a 78 y/o M h/o CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer
   who presents with new onset A. Fib with RVR and MSSA bacteremia, now
   with respiratory failure and ARF.
   .
   # Overall goal of care: Pt gravely ill, with bacteremia, hypotension,
   ARF and respiratory failure. After family meeting yesterday, family
   decided to forego further aggressive care or interventions, however not
   CMO. Will continue pressors for BP support and low-dose morphine gtt
   for pain control. Please see Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 242**]
s note from yesterday for
   details.
   .
   # Hemodynamic instability: Initially presented with A. Fib with RVR
   appears to be a new diagnosis for this patient. Patient converted to
   NSR post-TEE in the setting of hyperkalemia, and remained in NSR after
   electrolyte correction. Then back in A. fib yesterday AM but converted
   to SR with IV amio. Hemodynamically better when in NSR. Likely not a
   candidate for coumadin given recent GI bleed and colon cancer.  Patient
   has ruled out for an MI. Had TEE on [**3-11**] that showed no clot.
   - switch IV amio to PO
   - AICD turned off per family wishes given gravity of pt
s overall
   condition. Appreciate EP help.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Presented with subacute exacerbation with
   decline over past 3-4 weeks.  Has COPD at baseline. Patient was
   electively intubated on [**3-11**] to perform multiple procedures.  Difficulty
   weaning patient from the ventilator initially due to fluid retention
   and baseline COPD. Extubated afternoon of [**3-17**] but re-intubated [**3-18**] AM
   for increased work of breathing and tachypnea, worsening acidosis. Pt
   is 20L positive over LOS however will not diurese given ARF.  Tube
   feeds held overnight.
   - Continue mech ventilation until further direction from family.
   .
   # Fever/bacteremia:  Blood cultures 3/4 MSSA in setting of metastatic
   seeding of gouty joints
 likely due to endocarditis. Additional data
   is worsening necrosis of toes and mottling of L foot. BCx from anerobic
   bottle on [**3-14**] showing GNR. Sputum also showing enterobacter cloacae
   (sensitive to cefepime and cipro), likely representing VAP (however
   mini-BAL negative).
   - Switched abx from nafcillin (received 6 days
 worth, [**Date range (1) 4714**]), to
   Cipro, Cefepime and Flagyl (started evening of [**3-15**])
   - F/u final BCx and speciation/sensi studies to further tailor abx.
   - F/u ID recs (consider TEE in [**1-7**] weeks and CT torso when feasible)
   - f/u pending micro studies
   .
   # ARF: Most likely, initially pre-renal then tipped over to ATN. No
   urine eos, thus unlikely AIN due to nafcillin. No hydronephrosis per CT
   scan.  Mass lesion on the left previously seen on CT done [**2174-2-6**] at
   BIDN. Cr now somewhat stable in 4+ range.
   - Trend lytes
   - Renal c/s
 treat hyperphosphatemia with Renagel and increase dose of
   AlOH. No hemodialysis or biopsy as pt does not want aggressive
   interventions.
   - Renally dose meds
   .
   # Septic arthritis / gout: Patient septic arthritis combined with gouty
   arthritis in multiple joints.  Orthopedics took patient to the OR for
   washout on [**3-12**] and all joints tapped have bacteria on gram stain.
   Assistance and recs from ortho and rheum are much appreciated.
   - family does not wish any further procedures
   - colchicine off given elevated creatinine
   - Continue slow taper of steroids started [**3-14**]
   - Appreciate ortho recs
   .
   # Abdominal pain: Unable to assess recently in light of intubation and
   sedation. The patient did not have any abdominal pain on presentation.
   He had mild discomfort on exam over the weekend which is stable.
   Abdominal ultrasound also noted sludge in the gallbladder, no other
   findings noted.  Pain could be secondary to a bilary process,
   bacteremia (?abdominal abscess), or some other process related to his
   colon cancer.
   - Trend LFTs
 elevated Tbili, other LFTs and lipase nl
   - RUQ U/S showing cholelithiasis, no cholecystitis.
   .
   # Anemia: likely GIB from colon cancer and anemia of chronic dz.
   Patient transfused with 1 unit on am of [**3-13**] and 2 U [**3-14**]. Haptoglobin
   not decreased and LDH not largely elevated, so hemolysis less likely.
   Guaiac pos [**3-17**]
   - per BIDN records, baseline Hct 35-37.
   - goal Hct >22; judicious RBC transfusions.
   - Also exhibiting platelet drop, which might be multifactorial,
   including HIT and low-grade DIC.
   .
   # Colon Ca: No known mets but with extensive lymphadenopathy in chest
   on last CT scan.
   - had a colorectal outpt appt scheduled for [**3-16**]; will defer this issue
   until pt extubated and stabilized.
   .
   # Pressure Ulcers:
   - local wound care, frequent turns, monitor areas of peripheral
   necrosis
   .
   # Hyperglycemia: no h/o diabetes by chart.  HbA1c 6.7.  Continue
   humalog sliding scale q6h for now, given steroids.
   .
   # Glaucoma: continue eye drops
   - confirm pilocarpine dosing from outpatient setting.
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, ISS. NGT placed. Tube feeds.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: HSC, pneumoboots, PPI
   .

d [**3-17**] (placed

   .

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), congestive heart failure (CHF), and recently diagnosed colon cancer. He presents with new-onset atrial fibrillation (A. Fib) with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia. The patient also has respiratory failure and acute renal failure (ARF).

The patient initially presented with A. Fib with RVR but converted to normal sinus rhythm (NSR) post-transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) in the setting of hyperkalemia and remained in NSR after electrolyte correction. He then reverted back to A. Fib yesterday morning but converted to SR with intravenous amiodarone (IV amio). The patient is hemodynamically better when in NSR. He is not a candidate for warfarin (Coumadin) due to recent gastrointestinal (GI) bleed and colon cancer. The patient has ruled out the possibility of an acute myocardial infarction (MI). A TEE on 3/11 showed no clot. The switch from IV amio to oral amiodarone (PO) and discontinuation of the implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) have been discussed with the family due to the patient's overall condition. The family has declined further aggressive care or interventions, except for continued

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 35.7 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 72 beats per minute, blood pressure of 113/33 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. s note from yesterday for

   .

   - switch IV amio to PO
   - AICD turned off per family wishes given gravity of pt
s overall
   condition. Appreciate EP help.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Presented with subacute exacerbation with
   decline over past 3-4 weeks.  Has COPD at baseline. Patient was
   electively intubated on [**3-11**] to perform multiple procedures.  Difficulty
   weaning patient from the ventilator initially due to fluid retention
   and baseline COPD. Extubated afternoon of [**3-17**] but re-intubated [**3-18**] AM
   for increased work of breathing and tachypnea, worsening acidosis. Pt

 likely due to endocarditis. Additional data

The patient presents with new onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and MSSA bacteremia, now with respiratory failure and acute renal failure.

The overall goal of care is to provide comfort and support as the patient is gravely ill, with bacteremia, hypotension, ARF, and respiratory failure. The family has decided to forego further aggressive care or interventions, but not cardiopulmonary resuscitation. The plan includes continuing pressors for BP support, low-dose morphine for pain control, and monitoring.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation due to an exacerbation of COPD and fluid retention. The patient's inability to wean off the ventilator indicates difficulty in managing respiratory function. Close monitoring and adjustment of ventilator settings will be necessary.

2. Acute renal failure (ARF): The patient likely initially had pre-renal acute kidney injury which progressed to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). It is important to continue renal monitoring, manage electrolyte imbalances, and address hyperphosphatemia with Renagel and increased AlOH dose. Renal dosing of medications should also be considered.

3. Bacteremia and septic arthritis: The patient has MSSA bacteremia,

Summary:
The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, and recently diagnosed colon cancer who presents with new-onset atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, and acute renal failure. The patient was initially presented with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia. The patient converted to sinus rhythm post-transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) in the setting of hyperkalemia and remained in sinus rhythm after electrolyte correction. However, the patient converted back into atrial fibrillation yesterday morning but was successfully converted back into sinus rhythm with intravenous amiodarone. The patient has been hemodynamically better when in sinus rhythm. The patient is unlikely to be a candidate for warfarin given recent gastrointestinal bleeding and colon cancer. The patient has ruled out the possibility of an acute myocardial infarction. A TEE was performed on [3-11] that showed no clot. The patient appears to be in normal sinus rhythm but has multiple premature ventricular contractions (PVCs). Switch IV amiodarone to oral and turn off the implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) per family wishes due to the patient's overall condition.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 78 y/o M h/o CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer
   who presents with new onset A. Fib with RVR and MSSA bacteremia, now
   with respiratory failure and ARF.
   .
   # Overall goal of care: Pt gravely ill, with bacteremia, hypotension,
   ARF and respiratory failure.  Continuing pressors for BP support and
   low-dose morphine gtt for pain control.
   - Will meet with family again today re: goals of care
   .
   # Hemodynamic instability: Initially presented with A. Fib with RVR
   appears to be a new diagnosis for this patient. Patient converted to
   NSR post-TEE in the setting of hyperkalemia, and remained in NSR after
   electrolyte correction. Then back in A. fib yesterday AM but converted
   to SR with IV amio. Hemodynamically better when in NSR. Likely not a
   candidate for coumadin given recent GI bleed and colon cancer.  Patient
   has ruled out for an MI. Had TEE on [**3-11**] that showed no clot.
   - Appears to be in NSR but many PVCs
   - switch IV amio to PO
   - AICD turned off per family wishes on [**3-18**] given gravity of pt
   overall condition. Appreciate EP help.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Presented with subacute exacerbation with
   decline over past 3-4 weeks.  Has COPD at baseline. Patient was
   electively intubated on [**3-11**] to perform multiple procedures.  Difficulty
   weaning patient from the ventilator initially due to fluid retention
   and baseline COPD. Extubated afternoon of [**3-17**] but re-intubated [**3-18**] AM
   for increased work of breathing and tachypnea, worsening acidosis. Pt
   is over 20L positive over LOS however will not diurese given ARF.
   - Continue mech ventilation until further direction from family.
   .
   # Fever/bacteremia:  Blood cultures 3/4 MSSA in setting of metastatic
   seeding of gouty joints
 likely due to endocarditis. Additional data
   is worsening necrosis of toes and mottling of L foot. BCx from anerobic
   bottle on [**3-14**] showing GNR. Sputum also showing enterobacter cloacae
   (sensitive to cefepime and cipro), likely representing VAP (however
   mini-BAL negative).
   - Switched abx from nafcillin (received 6 days
 worth, [**Date range (1) 4714**]), to
   Cipro, Cefepime and Flagyl (started evening of [**3-15**]) for
   - MSSA bacteremia, Enterobacter in sputum, and B. fragilis in blood.
   - ID signed-off : will likely forego TEE and CT torso as family moving
   toward CMO
   - f/u pending micro studies
   .
   # ARF: Most likely, initially pre-renal then tipped over to ATN. No
   urine eos, thus unlikely AIN due to nafcillin. No hydronephrosis per CT
   scan.  Mass lesion on the left previously seen on CT done [**2174-2-6**] at
   BIDN. Cr now somewhat stable in 4+ range.
   - Trend lytes
   - Treating hyperphosphatemia with CaCO3 and lanthanum, will titrate up
   doses.  No hemodialysis or biopsy as pt does not want aggressive
   interventions.
   - Renally dose meds
   .
   # Septic arthritis / gout: Patient septic arthritis combined with gouty
   arthritis in multiple joints.  Orthopedics took patient to the OR for
   washout on [**3-12**] and all joints tapped have bacteria on gram stain.
   Assistance and recs from ortho and rheum are much appreciated.
   - family does not wish any further procedures
   - colchicine off given elevated creatinine
   - Steroid taper started [**3-14**], now off
   - Appreciate ortho recs
   .
   # Abdominal pain: Stable. Unable to assess recently in light of
   intubation and sedation. The patient did not have any abdominal pain on
   presentation.  He had mild discomfort on exam over the last weekend
   which is stable.  Abdominal ultrasound also noted sludge in the
   gallbladder, no other findings noted.  Pain could be secondary to a
   bilary process, bacteremia (?abdominal abscess), or some other process
   related to his colon cancer.
   - Trend LFTs
 elevated Tbili, other LFTs and lipase nl
   - RUQ U/S showing cholelithiasis, no cholecystitis.
   .
   # Anemia: likely GIB from colon cancer and anemia of chronic dz.
   Patient transfused with 1 unit on am of [**3-13**] and 2 U [**3-14**]. Haptoglobin
   not decreased and LDH not largely elevated, so hemolysis less likely.
   Guaiac pos [**3-17**]
   - per BIDN records, baseline Hct 35-37.
   - goal Hct >22; judicious RBC transfusions.
   - Also exhibiting platelet drop, which might be multifactorial,
   including HIT and low-grade DIC.
   - hct down to 19 this morning, will discuss goals of care with family
   today and decide whether to transfuse based on that.
   .
   # Colon Ca: No known mets but with extensive lymphadenopathy in chest
   on last CT scan.
   - had a colorectal outpt appt scheduled for [**3-16**]; will defer this issue
   until pt extubated and stabilized.
   .
   # Pressure Ulcers:
   - local wound care, frequent turns, monitor areas of peripheral
   necrosis
   .
   # Hyperglycemia: no h/o diabetes by chart.  HbA1c 6.7.  Steroid taper
   finished, will stop insulin sliding scale.
   .
   # Glaucoma: continue eye drops
   - confirm pilocarpine dosing from outpatient setting.
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, tube feeds via NGT.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: No HSC, pneumoboots, PPI
   .
   # Access: A-line ([**2174-3-11**]), and R IJ central line d/c
d [**3-17**] (placed
   [**2174-3-11**]), RUE PICC (placed [**3-17**])
   .
   # Code: DNR. Overall care plan discussion on-going with family.
   .
   # Communication: Patient,  Wife
   .
   # Disposition: Requires ICU level of care.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, and recently diagnosed colon cancer. He presents with new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia, now with respiratory failure and acute renal failure.

The patient initially presented with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which appears to be a new diagnosis. He converted to normal sinus rhythm post-transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) in the setting of hyperkalemia and remained in normal sinus rhythm after electrolyte correction. However, he reverted back to atrial fibrillation the next day morning but converted to sinus rhythm with intravenous amiodarone. He is hemodynamically better when in normal sinus rhythm. The patient has ruled out the possibility of an acute myocardial infarction. A TEE performed on [**3-11**] showed no clot.

The patient also presented with a subacute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with a decline over the past 3-4 weeks. He was electively intubated on [**3-11**] to perform multiple procedures. Due to fluid retention and baseline COPD, the patient initially had difficulty weaning from the ventilator.    Assessment and Plan
   This is a 78 y/o M h/o CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer
   who presents with new onset A. Fib with RVR and MSSA bacteremia, now
   with respiratory failure and ARF.
   .
   # Overall goal of care: Pt gravely ill, with bacteremia, hypotension,
   ARF and respiratory failure. After family meeting yesterday, family
   decided to forego further aggressive care or interventions, however not
   CMO. Will continue pressors for BP support and low-dose morphine gtt
   for pain control.
   - Will continue to speak with family re: goals of care
   .
   # Hemodynamic instability: Initially presented with A. Fib with RVR
   appears to be a new diagnosis for this patient. Patient converted to
   NSR post-TEE in the setting of hyperkalemia, and remained in NSR after
   electrolyte correction. Then back in A. fib yesterday AM but converted
   to SR with IV amio. Hemodynamically better when in NSR. Likely not a
   candidate for coumadin given recent GI bleed and colon cancer.  Patient
   has ruled out for an MI. Had TEE on [**3-11**] that showed no clot.
   - Appears to be in NSR but many PVCs
   - switch IV amio to PO
   - AICD turned off per family wishes given gravity of pt
s overall
   condition. Appreciate EP help.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Presented with subacute exacerbation with
   decline over past 3-4 weeks.  Has COPD at baseline. Patient was
   electively intubated on [**3-11**] to perform multiple procedures.  Difficulty
   weaning patient from the ventilator initially due to fluid retention
   and baseline COPD. Extubated afternoon of [**3-17**] but re-intubated [**3-18**] AM
   for increased work of breathing and tachypnea, worsening acidosis. Pt
   is 20L positive over LOS however will not diurese given ARF.  Tube
   feeds held overnight.
   - Titrate up pain meds as patient still in pain uncomfortable on the
   vent
   - Will f/u ABG this AM
   - Continue mech ventilation until further direction from family.
   .
   # Fever/bacteremia:  Blood cultures 3/4 MSSA in setting of metastatic
   seeding of gouty joints
 likely due to endocarditis. Additional data
   is worsening necrosis of toes and mottling of L foot. BCx from anerobic
   bottle on [**3-14**] showing GNR. Sputum also showing enterobacter cloacae
   (sensitive to cefepime and cipro), likely representing VAP (however
   mini-BAL negative).
   - Switched abx from nafcillin (received 6 days
 worth, [**Date range (1) 4714**]), to
   Cipro, Cefepime and Flagyl (started evening of [**3-15**])
   - F/u final BCx and speciation/sensi studies to further tailor abx.
   - F/u ID recs : will likely forego TEE and CT torso
   - f/u pending micro studies
   .
   # ARF: Most likely, initially pre-renal then tipped over to ATN. No
   urine eos, thus unlikely AIN due to nafcillin. No hydronephrosis per CT
   scan.  Mass lesion on the left previously seen on CT done [**2174-2-6**] at
   BIDN. Cr now somewhat stable in 4+ range.
   - Trend lytes
   - Renal c/s
 treat hyperphosphatemia with Renagel and increase dose of
   AlOH. No hemodialysis or biopsy as pt does not want aggressive
   interventions.
   - Renally dose meds
   .
   # Septic arthritis / gout: Patient septic arthritis combined with gouty
   arthritis in multiple joints.  Orthopedics took patient to the OR for
   washout on [**3-12**] and all joints tapped have bacteria on gram stain.
   Assistance and recs from ortho and rheum are much appreciated.
   - family does not wish any further procedures
   - colchicine off given elevated creatinine
   - Continue slow taper of steroids started [**3-14**]
   - Appreciate ortho recs
   .
   # Abdominal pain: Stable. Unable to assess recently in light of
   intubation and sedation. The patient did not have any abdominal pain on
   presentation.  He had mild discomfort on exam over the weekend which is
   stable.  Abdominal ultrasound also noted sludge in the gallbladder, no
   other findings noted.  Pain could be secondary to a bilary process,
   bacteremia (?abdominal abscess), or some other process related to his
   colon cancer.
   - Trend LFTs
 elevated Tbili, other LFTs and lipase nl
   - RUQ U/S showing cholelithiasis, no cholecystitis.
   .
   # Anemia: likely GIB from colon cancer and anemia of chronic dz.
   Patient transfused with 1 unit on am of [**3-13**] and 2 U [**3-14**]. Haptoglobin
   not decreased and LDH not largely elevated, so hemolysis less likely.
   Guaiac pos [**3-17**]
   - per BIDN records, baseline Hct 35-37.
   - goal Hct >22; judicious RBC transfusions.
   - Also exhibiting platelet drop, which might be multifactorial,
   including HIT and low-grade DIC.
   .
   # Colon Ca: No known mets but with extensive lymphadenopathy in chest
   on last CT scan.
   - had a colorectal outpt appt scheduled for [**3-16**]; will defer this issue
   until pt extubated and stabilized.
   .
   # Pressure Ulcers:
   - local wound care, frequent turns, monitor areas of peripheral
   necrosis
   .
   # Hyperglycemia: no h/o diabetes by chart.  HbA1c 6.7.  Continue
   humalog sliding scale q6h for now, given steroids.
   .
   # Glaucoma: continue eye drops
   - confirm pilocarpine dosing from outpatient setting.
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, ISS. Tube feeds via NGT.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: No HSC pneumoboots, PPI
   .
   # Access: A-line ([**2174-3-11**]), and R IJ central line d/c
d [**3-17**] (placed
   [**2174-3-11**]), RUE PICC (placed [**3-17**])
   .
   # Code: DNR/I. Overall care plan discussion on-going with family.
   .
   # Communication: Patient,  Wife
   .
   # Disposition: Requires ICU level of care.
   ICU Care

Summary:
The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), congestive heart failure (CHF), and recently diagnosed colon cancer. He presents with atrial fibrillation (A. Fib) with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia, now with respiratory failure and acute renal failure (ARF). The patient's family has decided to forego further aggressive care or interventions.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hemodynamic instability: The patient initially presented with A. Fib with RVR and converted to normal sinus rhythm (NSR) post-transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) in the setting of hyperkalemia. However, he converted back to A. Fib yesterday AM but was successfully converted to SR with IV amiodarone. Hemodynamic instability continues to be a concern.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient presented with a subacute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and was electively intubated on [**3-11**] to perform multiple procedures. Difficulty in weaning the patient from the ventilator initially due to fluid retention and baseline COPD led to re-intubation on [**3-18**] AM. The patient remains on mechanical ventilation.
3. Fever/bacteremia: Blood cultures showed MSSA in the setting of metastatic seeding of gouty

Summary:
The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, and recently diagnosed colon cancer. He presents with new-onset atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, bacteremia, septic arthritis, gout, abdominal pain, anemia, and pressure ulcers. The patient has been intubated multiple times due to difficulty weaning off the ventilator and worsening respiratory condition. He has been diagnosed with MSSA bacteremia, likely due to metastatic seeding of gouty joints, and has necrosis of toes and mottling of the left foot. The patient's condition is described as "gravely ill" with multiple organ dysfunction, and the family has decided to forego further aggressive care or interventions.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to a combination of underlying COPD and fluid retention. Intubation has been attempted multiple times, but the patient remains on mechanical ventilation.
2. Acute Kidney Injury (ARF): The patient's renal function has deteriorated, leading to acute kidney injury. This may be pre-renal initially, followed by acute tubular necrosis. The patient's elevated creatinine levels indicate impaired renal function.
3. Bacteremia and Septic Arthritis: The patient has MSSA bacteremia, which may have resulted in septic arthritis in multiple joints. Orthopedic intervention was considered, but

   This is a 78 y/o M h/o CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer
   who presents with new onset A. Fib with RVR and MSSA bacteremia, now
   with respiratory failure and ARF.
   .
   # Overall goal of care: Pt gravely ill, with bacteremia, hypotension,
   ARF and respiratory failure. After family meeting yesterday, family
   decided to forego further aggressive care or interventions, however not
   CMO. Will continue pressors for BP support and low-dose morphine gtt
   for pain control.

   .
   # Hemodynamic instability: Initially presented with A. Fib with RVR
   appears to be a new diagnosis for this patient. Patient converted to
   NSR post-TEE in the setting of hyperkalemia, and remained in NSR after
   electrolyte correction. Then back in A. fib yesterday AM but converted
   to SR with IV amio. Hemodynamically better when in NSR. Likely not a
   candidate for coumadin given recent GI bleed and colon cancer.  Patient
   has ruled out for an MI. Had TEE on [**3-11**] that showed no clot.
   - Appears to be in NSR but many PVCs
   - switch IV amio to PO
   - AICD turned off per family wishes given gravity of pt
s overall
   condition. Appreciate EP help.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Presented with subacute exacerbation with
   decline over past 3-4 weeks.  Has COPD at baseline. Patient was
   electively intubated on [**3-11**] to perform multiple procedures.  Difficulty
   weaning patient from the ventilator initially due to fluid retention
   and baseline COPD. Extubated afternoon of [**3-17**] but re-intubated [**3-18**] AM
   for increased work of breathing and tachypnea, worsening acidosis. Pt
   is 20L positive over LOS however will not diurese given ARF.  Tube
   feeds held overnight.
   - Titrate up pain meds as patient still in pain uncomfortable on the
   vent
   - Will f/u ABG this AM
   - Continue mech ventilation until further direction from family.
   .
   # Fever/bacteremia:  Blood cultures 3/4 MSSA in setting of metastatic
   seeding of gouty joints
 likely due to endocarditis. Additional data
   is worsening necrosis of toes and mottling of L foot. BCx from anerobic
   bottle on [**3-14**] showing GNR. Sputum also showing enterobacter cloacae

Summary:
The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, and recently diagnosed colon cancer. He presents with new onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia, now with respiratory failure and acute renal failure (ARF). The overall goal of care is to continue pressors for blood pressure support and low-dose morphine for pain control, as the patient's family has decided to forego further aggressive care or interventions.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hemodynamic instability: The patient initially presented with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which appears to be a new diagnosis. He converted to normal sinus rhythm post-transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) in the setting of hyperkalemia and remained in normal sinus rhythm after electrolyte correction. However, he converted back to atrial fibrillation yesterday morning but was successfully converted to sinus rhythm with intravenous amiodarone. He is likely not a candidate for warfarin due to recent gastrointestinal bleeding and colon cancer. The patient has ruled out the possibility of an acute myocardial infarction (MI). A TEE on [date] showed no clot, but the patient remains in normal sinus rhythm with many premature ventricular contractions (PVCs). Switch IV amiodarone to oral and turn off AICD per family wishes given

Summary:
The patient is a 78-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of colon cancer, new-onset atrial fibrillation, and MSSA bacteremia with multiple joint infections. He is currently experiencing persistent ventilatory failure, persistent renal failure, and impaired peripheral perfusion. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.7C, heart rate of 72 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 104/36 to 181/87 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin, normal platelet count, elevated creatinine, low total CO2, and normal electrolyte levels. Imaging shows a poor-quality chest X-ray with an endotracheal tube positioned 7 cm above the carina. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has continued assisted/controlled (A/C) support, and the endotracheal tube has been advanced by 3 cm. Continuous monitoring and adjustment of ventilatory support are necessary to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.

2. Sepsis/MSSA Bacteremia: The patient has been treated with multiple drainage procedures and antibiotic therapy, initially with Nafcillin but switched to Cefepime, Cipro, and Flagyl due to gram-negative rod contamination. It is essential to monitor the patient's response to antibiotics and continue appropriate infection

   This is a 78 y/o M h/o CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer
   who presented with new onset A. Fib with RVR and MSSA bacteremia, now
   complicated with respiratory failure and ARF.
   .
   # Overall goal of care: Pt gravely ill, with bacteremia, hypotension,
   ARF and respiratory failure.  Continuing pressors for BP support and
   low-dose morphine gtt for pain control.
   - Will meet with family again today re: goals of care
   .
   # Hemodynamic instability: Initially presented with A. Fib with RVR
   appears to be a new diagnosis for this patient. Has been in and out of
   a fib during his hospital stay. In NSR with many PVCs currently, with
   PO amio. Likely not a candidate for coumadin given recent GI bleed and
   colon cancer.  TEE on [**3-11**] showed no clot
   - Continue PO Amio.
   - AICD turned off per family wishes on [**3-18**] given gravity of pt
   overall condition. Appreciate EP help.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Presented with subacute exacerbation with
   decline over past 3-4 weeks.  Has COPD at baseline. Patient was
   electively intubated on [**3-11**] to perform multiple procedures. COPD.
   Extubated afternoon of [**3-17**] but re-intubated [**3-18**] AM for increased work
   of breathing and tachypnea, worsening acidosis.
   - Continue mech ventilation until further direction from family.
   .
   # Fever/bacteremia:  Blood cultures 3/4 MSSA in setting of metastatic
   seeding of gouty joints
 likely due to endocarditis. Additional data
   is worsening necrosis of toes and mottling of L foot. BCx from anerobic
   bottle on [**3-14**] showing GNR. Sputum also showing enterobacter cloacae
   (sensitive to cefepime and cipro), likely representing VAP (however
   mini-BAL negative).  WBC count higher today.
   - Switched abx from nafcillin (received 6 days
 worth, [**Date range (1) 4714**]), to
   Cipro, Cefepime and Flagyl (started evening of [**3-15**]) for MSSA
   bacteremia, Enterobacter in sputum, and B. fragilis in blood.
   - Ask ID whether Cipro can be stopped
   - Will add fluconazole for fungal coverage given worsening of
   leukocytosis
   - f/u pending micro studies
   .
   # ARF: Most likely, initially pre-renal then tipped over to ATN. No
   urine eos, thus unlikely AIN due to nafcillin. No hydronephrosis per CT
   scan.  Mass lesion on the left previously seen on CT done [**2174-2-6**] at
   BIDN. Cr now somewhat stable in 4+ range.
   - Trend lytes
   - Treating hyperphosphatemia with CaCO3 and lanthanum, will titrate up
   doses.  No hemodialysis or biopsy as pt does not want aggressive
   interventions.
   - Renally dose meds
   .
   # Septic arthritis / gout: Patient septic arthritis combined with gouty
   arthritis in multiple joints.  Orthopedics took patient to the OR for
   washout on [**3-12**] and all joints tapped have bacteria on gram stain.
   Assistance and recs from ortho and rheum are much appreciated.
   - family does not wish any further procedures
   - colchicine off given elevated creatinine
   - Steroid taper started [**3-14**], now off
   - Appreciate ortho recs
   .
   # Abdominal pain: Stable. Difficult to assess due to intubation and
   sedation. The patient did not have any abdominal pain on presentation.
   He had mild discomfort on exam over the last weekend which is stable.
   Abdominal ultrasound also noted sludge in the gallbladder, no other
   findings noted.  RUQ U/S showing cholelithiasis, no cholecystitis. Pain
   could be secondary to a bilary process, bacteremia (?abdominal
   abscess), or some other process related to his colon cancer.  Also
   having high residuals on tube feeds. Likely has functional ileus due to
   high amounts of morphine that patient is receiving.
   - check KUB for ileus
   - Repeat LFTs.
   # Anemia: likely GIB from colon cancer and anemia of chronic dz.
   Patient transfused with 1 unit on am of [**3-13**] and 2 U [**3-14**]. Haptoglobin
   not decreased and LDH not largely elevated, so hemolysis less likely.
   Guaiac pos [**3-17**]. Received 1 u pRBCs yesterday for Hct 19 with
   appropriate bump in Hct.
   - per BIDN records, baseline Hct 35-37.
   - goal Hct >22; judicious RBC transfusions.
   - Also exhibiting platelet drop, which might be multifactorial,
   including HIT and low-grade DIC.
   .
   # Colon Ca: No known mets but with extensive lymphadenopathy in chest
   on last CT scan.
   - had a colorectal outpt appt scheduled for [**3-16**]; will defer this issue
   until pt extubated and stabilized.
   .
   # Pressure Ulcers:
   - local wound care, frequent turns, monitor areas of peripheral
   necrosis
   .
   # Hyperglycemia: no h/o diabetes by chart.  HbA1c 6.7.  Steroid taper
   finished, thus insulin sliding scale was stopped
   .
   # Glaucoma: continue eye drops
   - confirm pilocarpine dosing from outpatient setting.
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, tube feeds via NGT.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: No HSC, pneumoboots, PPI
   .
   # Access: A-line was inadvertently pulled yesterday; will be replace it
   as non-invasive monitoring has correlated well with A-line readings. R
   IJ central line d/c
d [**3-17**] (placed [**2174-3-11**]), RUE PICC (placed [**3-17**])
   .
   # Code: DNR. Overall care plan discussion on-going with family.
   .
   # Communication: Patient,  Wife
   .
   # Disposition: Requires ICU level of care.

- The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, and recently diagnosed colon cancer.
- He presents with new-onset atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, and acute renal failure.
- The patient has been in the ICU since [**2174-3-11**] for multiple procedures and has been intubated due to fluid retention and baseline chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
- He developed bacteremia with methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) and has been treated with ciprofloxacin, cefepime, and metronidazole.
- The patient has septic arthritis combined with gouty arthritis in multiple joints and has undergone washout and joint tapping.
- He also has a mass lesion on the left kidney seen on a CT scan.
- The patient's condition is complicated by anemia, likely due to gastrointestinal bleeding from colon cancer and anemia of chronic disease.
- He has pressure ulcers, hyperglycemia, glaucoma, and requires tube feeds through a nasogastric tube (NGT).
- The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition requires ICU level of care.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's new-onset atrial fibrillation may lead to hemodynamic instability and the risk of embolic events such as stroke.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may result in inadequate oxygenation and ventilation, leading to further deterioration in his condition.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic kidney disease and require dialysis.
4. Bacteremia and Sepsis: The presence of MSSA bacteremia increases the risk of sepsis and associated complications such as septic shock and organ dysfunction.
5. Septic Arthritis/Gouty Arthritis: The patient's septic arthritis combined with gouty arthritis can lead to joint destruction and systemic complications.
6. Pressure Ulcers: The patient's pressure ulcers increase the risk of infection and can lead to complications such as cellulitis or osteomyelitis.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia can worsen his overall condition and increase the risk of complications during surgical procedures or medical interventions.
8. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia can lead to complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state if not properly managed.
9. Glaucoma: The patient's glaucoma can lead to vision loss if not managed appropriately.
10. Colon Cancer: The patient's colon cancer may progress and metastasize, leading to further complications and a poorer prognosis.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, and recently diagnosed colon cancer. The patient presented with new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and MSSA bacteremia, now complicated with respiratory failure and acute renal failure.

The patient's overall goal of care is to continue pressors for blood pressure support and low-dose morphine for pain control. The patient's family will meet again to discuss the goals of care.

Hemodynamic instability: The patient initially presented with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which appears to be a new diagnosis for this patient. The patient has been in and out of atrial fibrillation during his hospital stay. He is currently in sinus rhythm with many premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) and is on oral amiodarone (PO amio). He is unlikely to be a candidate for warfarin given his recent gastrointestinal bleed and colon cancer. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) on 3/11 showed no clot.

Respiratory failure: The patient presented with a subacute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with a decline over the past 3-4 weeks. He was electively intubated on 3/11 to perform multiple procedures. He was extubated in the afternoon of 3/17 but reintubated on 3/18 AM for increased work of breathing and tachypnea, worsening acidosis.

Fever/bacteremia: Blood cultures showed MSSA in the setting of metastatic seeding of gouty joints likely due to endocarditis. Additional data includes worsening necrosis of toes and mottling of the left foot. Blood cultures from an aerobic bottle on 3/14 showed Gram-negative rods (GNR). Sputum also showed Enterobacter cloacae, which is sensitive to cefepime and ciprofloxacin, likely representing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The white blood cell count is higher today.

Switched antibiotics from nafcillin (received 6 days worth,  Date range (1) 4714) to ciprofloxacin, cefepime, and metronidazole (started evening of 3/15) for MSSA bacteremia, Enterobacter in sputum, and B. fragilis in blood. Ask ID whether ciprofloxacin can be stopped. Will add fluconazole for fungal coverage given worsening leukocytosis. Follow-up pending microbiology studies.

Acute renal failure (ARF): Most likely, initially pre-renal then tipped over to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). No urine eosinophils, thus unlikely allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN) due to nafcillin. No hydronephrosis per CT scan. Mass lesion on the

Summary:
The patient is a 78-year-old male with diffuse bacteremia and sepsis, multiple metastatic foci of infection, persistent compromise of ventilation, renal function, hypotension, and mental status. The patient has been diagnosed with acute respiratory failure, atrial fibrillation, and acute renal failure. The patient's family has been informed about his condition, and the physician agrees with the resident's assessment and plan.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.6C, heart rate of 66 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 119/41 mmHg to 130/66 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%.
